dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so, uh, I was reading this report, right? And it says drug-related deaths in the US increased by a shocking twenty percent last year. Twenty percent!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so, uh, I was reading this report, right? And it says drug-related deaths in the U S increased by a shocking twenty percent last year. Twenty percent!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: I know! Right? Like, twenty percent. It's just, uh, it's mind-boggling. And that's just one piece of the puzzle.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know! Right? Like, twenty percent. It's just, uh, it's mind-boggling. And that's just one piece of the puzzle.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! Because then you look at, um, Baltimore, right? Residents in Roland Park, that's like, the wealthy, white neighborhood, they live sixteen years longer than people just a few miles away in Greenmount East. Sixteen years.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! Because then you look at, um, Baltimore, right? Residents in Roland Park, that's like, the wealthy, white neighborhood, they live sixteen years longer than people just a few miles away in Greenmount East. Sixteen years.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the United States, residents of Baltimores largely white and wealthy Roland Park neighborhood can expect to live 16 years longer than residents of the largely black, impoverished Greenmount East neighborhood, located just a few miles away.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Sixteen years! And this is in, like, the same city! It completely blows that whole idea of "no one left behind" from the SDGs out of the water, doesn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Sixteen years! And this is in, like, the same city! It completely blows that whole idea of no one left behind from the SDGs out of the water, doesn't it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This is no way to fulfill the pledge contained in the SDG framework, called the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, that no one will be left behind.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It does! I mean, worldwide, hunger is growing, malaria cases are up, mortality climbed eight percent in Sub-Saharan Africa since 2021. It's just, it's not looking good.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It does! I mean, worldwide, hunger is growing, malaria cases are up, mortality climbed eight percent in Sub-Saharan Africa since twenty twenty one. It's just, it's not looking good.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Last years United Nations report on progress toward achieving the SDGs showed that the number of people facing hunger is actually growing, as is the number of malaria cases.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and the climate change stuff too, like, it's happening so much faster than they thought, with these catastrophic floods. The most vulnerable are getting hammered.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and the climate change stuff too, like, it's happening so much faster than they thought, with these catastrophic floods. The most vulnerable are getting hammered.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, according to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, the consequences of climate change are emerging much faster than anticipated. The worlds poorest and most vulnerable will be disproportionately affected.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally hammered. And then childhood immunization rates? They've just plummeted in developing nations, uh, probably because of COVID disruption, I guess.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally hammered. And then childhood immunization rates? They've just plummeted in developing nations, uh, probably because of COVID disruption, I guess.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but even before that, you see it, right? Nigeria, access to basic health interventions, it's five times higher for the wealthiest. Five times!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but even before that, you see it, right? Nigeria, access to basic health interventions, it's five times higher for the wealthiest. Five times!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In Nigeria, access to basic reproductive, maternal, newborn, and child health interventions remains five times higher for those in the top wealth quintile than those in the lowest (68%, compared to 13%).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, so like sixty-eight percent for the rich, thirteen for the poor. It's just... it's not a mistake.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, so like sixty-eight percent for the rich, thirteen for the poor. It's just... it's not a mistake.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In Nigeria, access to basic reproductive, maternal, newborn, and child health interventions remains five times higher for those in the top wealth quintile than those in the lowest (68%, compared to 13%).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, it's systemic. These inequities, they're not, um, accidental. They're built in.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, it's systemic. These inequities, they're not, um, accidental. They're built in.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So what do we do? Like, the MDGs made some progress, but poor people still fell further behind.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So what do we do? Like, the MDGs made some progress, but poor people still fell further behind.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The SDGs predecessor, the Millennium Development Goals, brought modest improvements in health equity for many countries, but in a substantial minorityof countries, poorer segments of the population fell even further behind.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the O'Neill Institute, they have this framework, these health equity programs of action. It's about tackling, um, the power, money, and resource distribution directly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the O'Neill Institute, they have this framework, these health equity programs of action. It's about tackling, um, the power, money, and resource distribution directly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Ensuring that the SDGs succeed where the MDGs did not demands a carefully designed, comprehensive, and inclusive response that directly tackles the inequitable distribution of power, money, and resources that underlies health inequities. The health equity programs of actionframework, proposed by the ONeill Institute for National and Global Health Law at the Georgetown University Law Center, aims to facilitate the development of just such a response.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, like, empowering participation? Getting people from marginalized groups to be decision-makers? Yes, exactly! That makes so much sense.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, like, empowering participation? Getting people from marginalized groups to be decision-makers? Yes, exactly! That makes so much sense.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Enable empowering participation and inclusive leadership. People from disadvantaged and marginalized populations would be decision-makers, helping to lead all relevant structures and processes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And looking beyond just the health system itself, to, like, all the social, environmental, economic determinants. That's key.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And looking beyond just the health system itself, to, like, all the social, environmental, economic determinants. That's key.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Health systems and beyond. The full range of social, cultural, environmental, economic, and political determinants of health must be considered.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Because we've got, what, less than twelve years now for the SDGs? We can't afford to mess this up again.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Because we've got, what, less than twelve years now for the SDGs? We can't afford to mess this up again.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We have less than 12 years to achieve the SDGs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Nope. And the good news, um, the article says it too: health inequities aren't inevitable. We can actually, like, fix these injustices.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Nope. And the good news, um, the article says it too: health inequities aren't inevitable. We can actually, like, fix these injustices.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Health inequities are not inevitable. They are the product of injustices that people have created. Eliminating those injustices is within our power as well.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, we have the power to fix them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, we have the power to fix them.
